title: Supreme Court temporarily allows Trump administration to shield DOGE documents
summary: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday temporarily allowed the Trump administration to shield Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency from freedom of information requests seeking thousands of pages of material.
story: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday temporarily allowed the Trump administration to shield Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency from freedom of information requests seeking thousands of pages of material.
Chief Justice John Roberts issued an administrative stay that puts lower court decisions on hold while the Supreme Court considers what next steps to take.
For now, it means the government will not have to respond to requests for documents and allow for the deposition of the DOGE administrator, Amy Gleason, as a lower court had ruled.

At issue in the ongoing litigation is whether DOGE, which has played a key role in firing government workers and cutting federal grants and spending, is technically a government agency and therefore subject to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), which allows members of the public to seek internal documents.
The Trump administration says that, despite its name, DOGE is merely a presidential advisory body that is not subject to public records requests under FOIA.

Further complicating matters, when DOGE was set up, it effectively took the place of a previous government entity called the U.S. Digital Service. The Trump administration now refers to the body as the U.S. DOGE Service, or USDS.

The case arose when watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) brought a freedom of information request in January soon after Trump took office seeking information about DOGE. CREW later filed suit.

In March, U.S. District Court Judge Christopher Cooper in Washington ruled DOGE is “likely” covered by FOIA and that “the public would be irreparably harmed by an indefinite delay in unearthing the records CREW seeks.”

Cooper ordered DOGE to process CREW’s several FOIA requests for information on an “expedited timetable” and to begin producing documents on a rolling basis “as soon as practicable.” The court also ordered the government to preserve “all records” that may be responsive to CREW’s FOIA requests.

In addition to the more than 100,000 documents the Office of Management and Budget has that are responsive to the FOIA request ordered by Cooper, DOGE itself said it has approximately 58,000 documents responsive to the request.
The documents in question all relate back to the question of whether DOGE is a government agency.

CREW's lawyers said in court papers said that Cooper had merely issued a "narrowly-tailored discovery order" to ascertain whether DOGE is a federal agency. The Supreme Court, they added, "rarely intervenes in ongoing discovery disputes" and there was "no basis for such extraordinary intervention here."

title: What is normal pressure hydrocephalus? Billy Joel's condition is often treatable
summary: Billy Joel announced Friday that he was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus after having trouble with his hearing, vision and balance.
story: The brain disorder that forced Billy Joel to cancel his concert tour can cause trouble walking and thinking straight — but is often treatable and can even be reversed, doctors said.

A post on the 76-year-old singer’s Instagram on Friday said that he was recently diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus and that concert performances exacerbated problems with his “hearing, vision, and balance.”
The condition is relatively uncommon, according to the Cleveland Clinic, affecting “about 5.9% of people over 80.”
It’s most commonly diagnosed in older adults, usually showing up around age 70.
What is normal pressure hydrocephalus?
The human body is constantly trying to keep a steady level of cerebrospinal fluid to cushion the brain and spinal cord, either by making more or absorbing it.

That fluid tends to take up a little more space in older adults because brain volume shrinks as a normal part of the aging process, said Dr. Wajd Al-Holou, a neurosurgeon at the University of Michigan Health.
"But what happens in normal pressure hydrocephalus is an abnormal buildup of fluid that causes brain dysfunction because of the pressure it's putting on the brain," he said.
What are the symptoms and how is it diagnosed?
Patients are often diagnosed after they see a doctor because they — or a family member — are concerned they might be developing dementia, which is also more common as people age.
Memory loss, bladder control issues and trouble walking are also common. Patients can have trouble lifting their feet, putting them at risk for stumbling and falling.

Doctors often learn about normal pressure hydrocephalus and its three hallmark symptoms with this catchphrase: 'wet, wobbly and weird,' said Dr. Vikram Udani, a neurosurgeon in private practice in San Diego.
"The 'weird' is the cognitive issue, typically things like memory problems or confusion, and the 'wobbly' stands for gait instability," he said. "The 'wet' is the urinary incontinence."
Brain imaging, either a CT scan or an MRI, is generally used to look for the buildup of fluid, as well as a variety of neurological testing.
Doctors may also do what’s called a lumbar puncture to drain the excess fluid. If the person’s symptoms improve, the condition is often diagnosed as normal pressure hydrocephalus, or NPH.
Udani said no one knows what causes the condition, but added that it's highly unlikely that loud music or concert touring would trigger NPH.
How is it treated?
It can look like dementia, but there’s a key difference: normal pressure hydrocephalus is treatable and in many cases reversible if it’s caught early.

Commonly, neurosurgeons implant a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, or tube, into the brain that helps drain the fluid buildup into another part of the body, like the abdomen. The patient then essentially pees the excess fluid out, Udani said.
A drug called acetazolamide can also be used, as it may help the body decrease the level of fluid on its own. The medicine doesn’t work for everyone, Al-Holou said.
It was unclear Friday what kind of treatment Joel would receive. His social media post said that the singer “is undergoing specific physical therapy,” but did not give details.
That kind of therapy is usually given, doctors said, to help patients regain balance.
Any treatment is more effective if a diagnosis is made quickly. If the condition goes on too long unchecked, it could lead to permanent brain damage, Al-Holou said.
If a person seems to be experiencing early signs such as troublesome memory loss and difficulty walking, “they should see a primary care physician or neurologist to investigate further,” he said.

title: Kim Kardashian Speaks Out After Paris Armed Robbery Trial Verdict
summary: Kim Kardashian released a statement after nine people were convicted of crimes connected to her Paris hotel robbery in 2016.
story: Kim Kardashian is speaking out after a panel of judges and jurors reached a verdict in her jewelry heist trial.

In 2016 during Paris Fashion Week, Kardashian, 44, was held at gunpoint in her hotel room as a number of people stole $9 million  worth of her jewelry, including a 20-carat diamond ring gifted to her by then-husband Kanye “Ye” West, according to prosecutors.

On May 23, eight people were convicted of crimes connected to the robbery, while one was acquitted. One defendant was convicted on a weapons charge that was not directly tied to the robbing of Kardashian. Most of the 10 defendants are in their 60s and 70s.
Upon hearing the news, the Skims co-founder expressed her gratitude and commitment to advocating for justice in a statement.

“I am deeply grateful to the French authorities for pursuing justice in this case. The crime was the most terrifying experience of my life, leaving a lasting impact on me and my family,” Kardashian said in a statement. “While I’ll never forget what happened, I believe in the power of growth and accountability and pray for healing for all. I remain committed to advocating for justice, and promoting a fair legal system.”

Kardashian’s legal team — Michael Rhodes, Léonor Hennerick, and Jonathan Mattout — also stated that she appreciates the court’s decision and thanked French authorities “for treating her with great respect throughout the process.”
They noted it has been a long journey “from that terrible night back in 2016 to her standing courageously in a historic Paris courtroom to confront these criminals.”
The trial began April 28 in Paris, France, and included testimony from those involved in the robbery, as well as Kardashian's childhood friend and Kardashian herself.
On May 13, the entrepreneur testified inside the Palais de Justice in Paris, France, where she shared details about the experience, including how she begged for her life.
Additionally, a letter from one of the people involved in the heist, Aomar Ait Khedache, 69, was read, in which he apologized for the trauma he put Kardashian through.
During the final court hearing on May 23, defendant Yunice Abbas said in a statement, “I have nothing but regrets to offer you and will take my responsibilities.”
The 72-year-old had previously written a book about the experience titled, “I Kidnapped Kim Kardashian.”

The mother of four’s legal team added in their statement that following the trial, Kardashian “looks forward to putting this tragic episode behind her, as she continues working to improve the criminal justice system on behalf of victims, the innocent, and the incarcerated seeking to redeem themselves.”

The verdict comes days after Kardashian completed her law program. “The Kardashians” star has been vocal about her passion for prison reform and criminal justice over the years. In a 2019 interview with Vogue, she said it was a factor in her choice to pursue a legal education.
Kardashian’s late father, Robert Kardashian, was a lawyer and served as one of O.J. Simpson's defense attorneys in his 1995 murder trial.

title: Billy Joel Cancels All Performances Following Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus Diagnosis
summary: Billy Joel has cancelled all upcoming shows because he's been diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus, a condition that has impacted his vision and balance.
story: Billy Joel is canceling all of his upcoming concert dates after being diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus or NPH.

The "Piano Man" singer, 76, announced his diagnosis May 23 in an official statement shared across his official social media accounts. "This condition has been exacerbated by recent concert performances, leading to problems with hearing, vision, and balance," the statement reads.
The legendary musician is currently undergoing "specific" physical therapy and had been advised to "refrain from performing," it continues to say.
Joel is “fully committed to prioritizing his health” and is looking forward to “the day he when he can once again take the stage,” it reads.
The statement also says Joel is grateful for both his medical team’s care and for his fans’ support.
"I’m sincerely sorry to disappoint our audience, and thank you for understanding," Joel adds in a personal message.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus happens when cerebrospinal fluid builds up inside the skull and puts pressure on the brain, according to the Cleveland Clinic. The condition is common in those 65 and older. It is treatable and sometimes reversible.
NPH’s symptoms often resemble those of dementia or Parkinson’s, TODAY.com previously reported. Subtle signs of NPH include shuffling, unsteady gait, bladder incontinence and memory problems.
Treatment for NPH typically involves surgery to drain fluid from the brain.
Joel’s medical update comes amid months of speculation about the five-time Grammy winner’s health.
On Feb. 22, Joel fell onstage while performing at the Mohegan Sun Arena in Uncasville, Connecticut, according to multiple videos shared by concertgoers.
The following month, Joel postponed his concert tour due to an unspecified medical condition.
A statement from Joel’s team at the time revealed Joel would be undergoing surgery and physical therapy as part of his treatment and was “expected to make a full recovery.”

title: Who is the Killer in ‘Fear Street: Prom Queen’? The Stars Explain Shadyside’s Latest Murders
summary: Who is the killer in "Fear Street: Prom Queen"? Does the movie connect to the original trilogy? All your questions about the horror film and its ending, answered.
story: Warning: This post has spoilers for the ending of “Fear Street: Prom Queen.”

Fans of the "Fear Street" franchise know to expect a few things from a new installment: blood, witchcraft and high school terror. "Fear Street: Prom Queen," which premiered on Netflix May 23, delivers all of the above — this time taking viewers to the cursed town of Shadyside in the '80s, in classic slasher style.
The movie follows outsider Lori Granger (India Fowler) whose social status is low as everyone believes her mother murdered her father.
"I played it as though she had this intuitive rejection towards that story," India Fowler tells TODAY.com. "She wasn't going to accept it."

Lori decides to run for prom queen, believing that “it’s time for something to change.” She runs against five other girls for the coveted title, but one in particular seems to be Lori's biggest competition: her longtime bully Tiffany Falconer (Fina Strazza).
When prom night comes around, it's revealed that two serial killers are roaming the grounds, secretly picking off the six unfortunate prom queen candidates — and their dates — one by one.
Who is the killer and what are their motives?

Unaware of all the killings, Lori sneaks away from the dancing promgoers with crush Tyler (David Iacono) for a private moment. The killer discovers them and immediately kills Tyler. Lori makes a quick escape, running into her friend Megan (Suzanna Son) who is also fleeing the killer. The two eventually make it back to prom and try to warn everyone about the danger. But everyone ignores them as Lori is crowned prom queen and pulled up onto the stage.

She begs for people to listen to her, but nobody does, before the killer cuts through the crowd with an axe. He then gets on the stage and tries to kill Lori, but Megan jumps on him, giving Lori the opportunity to plunge the crown into his eye. He falls to the ground in pain and pulls his mask off, revealing that Tiffany's dad, Dan Falconer (Chris Klein), is the culprit.
In front of everyone, he admits to his wife and daughter that he did it "because I knew how much you wanted it, both of you."

His wife, Nancy Falconer (Katherine Waterston), is shocked by the revelation, but stays behind to answer the police's questions as Tiffany and Lori — who happen to be neighbors — are sent home with police officers.
In the car ride home, Tiffany begins her redemption, apologizing to Lori and admitting that she was "never good enough" for her parents, and she's always "felt like nothing."

"You start to sympathize with her," Fowler says. "And I definitely, when reading the script, sympathized with Tiffany because it’s back to that kind of teenage girl going through mental turmoil. You start seeing her as this real human, young woman."
Finna Strazza describes her character as just being a "product of her environment."
"She has always had a lot of pressure put on her her whole life, by her family, by her peers," she adds.
When the girls finally reach their homes, Tiffany asks Lori not to leave. Lori offers to stay and goes inside, and the two spark a "potential friendship" after the night's bloody events, Fowler says.
"Lori will always choose to care for somebody and choose to be selfless," Fowler says.

Eventually, Nancy Falconer gets home, but she's not a concerned mother — she's another killer. She grabs a knife and begins chasing the girls through the house while humming. Terrified, they hide in the closet. There, Tiffany begins freaking out that both her parents are dangerous, yet it turns out she is, too. Tiffany pulls out a knife and tries to kill Lori.
Strazza says this part was not initially in the script.

“The original version I read, Tiffany was not involved at all, and it was just the parents,” she says. “In the scene that I was doing for my audition, she was just crying, and was like, ‘Mom, how could you do this?’”
Director Matt Palmer had her improvise being the killer during her final audition. Strazza landed the part, and the script was altered so she was involved in the gruesome finale.

Even with the threat of Tiffany, Lori escapes, running into the hallway where Nancy stabs her in the shoulder blade. With Lori injured, Nancy admits that she used to date Lori's dad and reveals she killed him after he left her for Lori's mom. Nancy prepares to kill Lori, but Tiffany asks to do it.
"I warned you," Tiffany tells Lori before Lori kicks her, sending her flying over the banister where she is then impaled on a table decoration below.

Strazza says that she always likes to do her own stunts, and this 12-foot fall was no different. She describes it as a "roller coaster." But when it came time for the impalement, that was a silicone mold.

"They made an entirely silicone mold of my entire body, where I was first covered in silicone," she says. "And while that hardened, they covered that in plaster, so I was just kind of stuck as this statue. It ended up taking six and a half hours to get my whole body, but the artistry that was involved in that was so impressive because it looked exactly like me. And it was kind of spooky to see that on set."
"I would walk past my own dead body, which was frightening," she adds.
What does Lori's final line mean?

With just Nancy left, Lori tries to escape, but the doors are locked. Eventually, Lori grabs a trophy and whacks Nancy in the head with it. She falls to the ground, slowly dying as she begs Lori for help.
But Lori just walks away as Nancy spews insults, calling her "trash," "nothing" and a "nobody."
Nancy's final words before slumping to her death are, "Who the f--- do you think you are?"
"I'm Lori f---ing Granger," Lori responds.
Fowler considers the whole film to be Lori's journey to "self-realization," with this final moment being her true acceptance of self.
"'I’m Lori f---ing Granger' is that moment," she says. "It’s earnest. And she really has gone through it. And been there, like you’ve seen her go through the turmoil."
Fowler believes that after the film ends, Lori is "definitely traumatized," but she hopes she comes to terms with what has happened.
"It would be interesting to imagine how she deals with self-redemption and self-acceptance, which I hope she's experiencing post film," she says.
What does the end credit scene mean?

Even though the film is on Netflix, stick around a little longer for an end credit scene. Although it's brief, fans of the "Fear Street" franchise will recognize the end credit scene ties the film back to the original trilogy.

The end credit scene shows Nancy Falconer's dead body lying on the ground, blood oozing from her head. But then, the blood begins to form into the Witch's Mark — also known as the Devil’s Mark from the original franchise.
In the initial trilogy, the Witch's Mark was where Shadyside residents were sacrificed by the Goode family to Satan.
Fowler calls this moment "a nod to the curse" from the original trilogy and a way for their film to "pay homage" to the origins.

"This film is its own thing," she says. "You don't necessarily have to watch the first three to understand this film, but I think that they did such a good job of doing the subtle nod to the fact that Shadyside is a cursed town, and it's inescapable and it's still apparent."

She adds that the end credits aren't the only "Easter egg" to the original trilogy. In fact, at the beginning of the film, there's a small shrine to everyone who died in the 1978 camp massacre, alluding to the events of the second film.
Were the Falconers cursed?
With that in mind, it begs the question: Was the Falconer family another victim of the curse of Shadyside?
Strazza thinks so.
"I think there's something in the water," she says. "I think that it's not a coincidence that these crazy people end up on the loose. Who knows who is connected to the Falconers in the past?"
Personally, Strazza thinks Tiffany "sold her soul to the devil."
One potential reason? Strazza pitches a search for "forever beauty."
"That would be something the Falconers would be into," she adds.

title: Fina Strazza says her ‘Fear Street: Prom Queen’ audition changed the movie’s ending
summary: FIna Strazza's ending to Fear Street: Prom Queen changed the movie's ending and made Tiffany a killer. Here's what to know.
story: Warning: This post has spoilers for the ending of "Fear Street: Prom Queen."
“Fear Street: Prom Queen" takes audiences back to the '80s for a prom night that goes from bodacious to, well, filled with bodies.

The newest installment to the "Fear Street" franchise follows outsider Lori Granger (India Fowler) as she runs for her high school's prom queen, going up against popular girl Tiffany Falconer (Fina Strazza) and her friends.
But on prom night, each girl nominated is picked off one by one, slasher style, by a serial killer.

Eventually, Tiffany's dad (Chris Klein) is revealed to be the killer — one of them, at least. After the big reveal, the police take a shocked Tiffany and Lori home as Mrs. Falconer (Katherine Waterston) stays to answer more questions. Tiffany asks Lori to come inside as she doesn't want to be alone, and Lori obliges.

But when Mrs. Falconer eventually gets home, she pulls out a knife and begins chasing both girls around the house. They hide in a closet as Tiffany freaks out over her parents both being psychotic killers.
But the apple doesn't fall far from the tree. Tiffany soon pulls out a knife and tries to kill Lori herself, revealing the final twist: All three Falconers were in on it together.
Fina Strazza, who plays Tiffany in the film, tells TODAY.com that this ending wasn't initially in the script. At first, her character was completely innocent.

"The original version I read, Tiffany was not involved at all, and it was just the parents," she says. "In the scene that I was doing for my audition, she was just crying, and was like, 'Mom, how could you do this?'"

Then, in the final audition over Zoom, casting director Carmen Cuba and director Matt Palmer decided to test another layer to her character. They asked Strazza to improvise the scene as if she were the killer.
"I was a little bit put on the spot," she admits. "I was a little nervous about that, because that’s a big responsibility to take on in just one moment."
"I did a little something, and afterwards, Matt and Carmen were like, 'Don’t you think that’s kind of cool?' I was like, 'Yeah, it was awesome.' I guess it worked," she says. "It landed me the part."
Strazza says she's "always loved horror movies" and "always wanted to play a killer."

Strazza's co-star India Fowler, who played Lori Granger in the film, tells TODAY.com she has mixed feelings on the movie's ending. Part of her "loves" it because it's so "shocking," but another part wishes the original ending could have made the cut. She says that part of her would have liked to see Tiffany and Lori form a friendship ... or even more.

"There's another side of me, which sort of thinks that Tiffany and Lori, there's a secret love affair going on," she says. "And so, I have this kind of inward dream that there's a universe where Tiffany is innocent and actually she's expressing her love for Lori in a weird way."
Fowler adds that Strazza was not alone in being directed to improvise certain moments. For the teens' dance battle, Strazza was taught classic '80s choreography, but Fowler was asked to improvise.

"Matt (Palmer) thought it was important that Lori didn't have any form of choreography," Fowler says. "They really just said, 'Feel free to just be free and dance' ... That was just left up to me, which I quite liked."

title: Kim Kardashian Got a Pretty Sweet Gift from Scott Disick After Completing Law Program
summary: Scott Disick gifted Kim Kardashian a beautiful "Legally Blonde" cake after she completed a law program that took her six years to finish.
story: Scott Disick gave Kim Kardashian the sweetest gift after she completed a law program that took her six years to finish.

On her Instagram story, Kardashian shared a photo of a three-tier cake that was inspired by the hit movie "Legally Blonde," which stars Reese Witherspoon as sorority girl Elle Woods who fuels her rage from a breakup into a journey to law school.
The sweet treat, which was decorated in pink and brown frosting, had "Legally Graduated" written across the front in gold letters and "Kim is my Lawyer" branded at the bottom in black.
"OMG this cake!!! Thank you," Kardashian wrote on her Instagram story. She also tagged Disick, who previously dated Kourtney Kardashian and is the father of their three kids.

Though the reality TV star does not have an undergraduate degree, she did pursue a nontraditional legal education through a process known as “reading the law,” a program available in California and a number of other states.
The approach allows individuals an opportunity to qualify for the bar exam in an eligible state after learning from a licensed attorney.
In an Instagram post, Kardashian talked about her great achievement and said she's glad she never gave up.
"Six years ago, I embarked on an unconventional path to pursue my dream of becoming a lawyer. It wasn’t easy, and it took longer than planned, but I never gave up," she wrote.

"Each course brought moments of doubt, tears, and triumph — especially when I conquered subjects I initially feared. That’s the beauty of life: you step into the unknown, push through, and emerge with knowledge and strength no one can take away," she continued.
The Skims founder noted that she was happy to have Chris Young, Michelle West and Dawn Jackson speak at her graduation ceremony as she was the one who “championed for their release from prison.”
"Their deeply personal stories of perseverance through adversity and injustice profoundly inspires me and form the heart of my 'why,'" she said.
Kardashian then gave thanks to a few more people, including mentors Jessica Jackson and Erin Haney, before she revealed what completing her law program meant to her.
"This experience has shaped me profoundly, and I’ll carry its lessons with me forever," she said. "Here’s to celebrating resilience and new beginnings! ⚖️🎓."

title: Get a Glimpse at the Harry Potter and the Battle at the Ministry Ride in Epic Universe
summary: Get a glimpse at Harry Potter and the Battle at the Ministry, from the atrium to the queue and the souvenir you can purchase at the end of the ride.
story: Muggles are chuffed over the opening of Harry Potter and the Battle at the Ministry ride, and for good reason.

Universal Epic Universe in Orlando, Florida, is the latest major theme park to debut in the U.S., which officially opened May 22. The theme park has five different worlds with more than 50 new attractions, including the buzzed-about ride at The Wizarding World of Harry Potter—Ministry of Magic.

The premise takes place after Lord Voldemort has been defeated, and Dolores Umbridge is being put on trial. Guests enter a lift and soon after the ride begins, they are greeted by Harry, Ron and Hermione, all of whom are on their way to see Umbridge’s trial. However, things take a turn when Umbridge escapes, and a quest to stop her before she does permanent damage ensues.

Thought people can visit Epic Universe right now, it might take some time to actually get to the front of the line due to popular demand. To hold you over, TODAY.com got a sneak peek at Harry Potter and the Battle at the Ministry prior to its official opening.
(Universal is owned by TODAY.com’s parent company, NBCUniversal.)
The entrance

The entrance to Harry Potter and the Battle at the Ministry is marked with a sign that reads “Metrofloo” over a tunnel-like opening. The Metrofloo is inspired by the Floo Network in the “Harry Potter” franchise, which is a mass transit system that lets wizards and witches travel to and from places including the Ministry of Magic, or the government of the British wizarding world.

It’s important to note that upon entering, there is a line for group riders and another line that combines single riders and a viewing-only experience of the Ministry of Magic atrium. In other words, you don’t have to wait in the riders line in order to see the atrium.
The Metrofloo

After walking through the Metrofloo’s tunnel, guests will come to an area with several entryways illuminated in green. Once they get the OK from a team member, guests can proceed through the opening as green smoke puffs around them, resembling that of floo powder (used in the “Harry Potter” franchise to transport wizards and witches.)
Visitors then walk through a smaller tunnel until coming across a second entryway, which puffs out another round of green smoke.
The Ministry of Magic atrium
After getting through the second round of green smoke, visitors are officially in the atrium of the Ministry of Magic.
Lined with thousands of subway tiles, the expansive tunnel leads to the Fountain of Magical Brethren, showing gold statues of a witch, a goblin and a house elf.
A large moving poster toggles between a headline about Umbridge’s trial, Umbridge herself and Kingsley Shacklebolt, an Auror (law enforcement official) for the Ministry of Magic.
Another gold statue stands at the back of the atrium, which appears to depict a wizard pointing their wand up toward the sky.
The queue
While you may have to wait to board the ride, the queue sets the stage for the advantage that awaits. First, there’s a room with reception booths and posters of wanted wizards hanging on the walls.
In the Hall of Ministers, guests encounter a bust of the first-ever minister of magic, Ulick Gamp, interacting with the other moving pictures in the room.

Perhaps the most notable room is Umbridge’s regal office, where her belongings are scattered or thrown into packing boxes. Her house elf, Higgledy, sits atop her furniture — and it’s certainly not the last you see of her.
The lift and ride premise
Once visitors arrive at the end of the queue, there are several lifts with two rows of seats awaiting guests.

Once settled, the ride will take you to a motion simulator screen where Harry, Ron and Heroine greet riders on the way to see Umbridge’s trial. However, a turn of events unfold as Umbridge escapes and a Death Eater comes to her aid. The rest of the journey sees the trio of best friends fight to capture Umbridge  and make sure justice is served.
Post-ride souvenir

Like many rides, a photo is taken during the experience and is available for purchase at the end. But instead a thematic frame, the picture is printed on the latest issue of The Daily Prophet. Extra, extra, read all about it!

title: What Is Joe Jonas’ ‘Work It Out’ About? He Pulls Back the Curtain on This 1 Lyric
summary: Joe Jonas tells TODAY's Craig Melvin about his new album “Music for People Who Believe in Love” and his song “Work It Out.”
story: Joe Jonas is opening up about the inspiration behind his long-awaited sophomore solo album, “Music for People Who Believe in Love,” out May 23.
The Jonas Brothers musician, 35, sat down with TODAY’s Craig Melvin to talk about working on the deeply personal record, including one of his most candid tracks, his single “Work It Out.”
Jonas told Craig he wrote the song after realizing he had to find his own way out of sorrow. “Nobody’s gonna save you now. Nobody’s gonna pull you out,” Jonas sings on the song’s chorus.
“I was really sad and in my head, and I felt like — this was last year at one point. ... I came to a realization that no one’s going to kind of get me out of the funk that I was in,” Jonas said.
Eventually, Jonas realized, “I think I just gotta shake this off and, like, have a conversation with myself and carry on,” he said.
Jonas said he hopes “Work It Out,” which he co-wrote with songwriters Blush and Jason Evigan, will inspire listeners to know that they can also rise above their challenges.
“It’s kind of pitching it to other people and saying, ‘You got this too,’” he said.

Though “Music for People Who Believe in Love” comes nearly two years after Jonas’ divorce from actor Sophie Turner, with whom he shares daughters Willa, 4, and Delphine, 2, the “funk” he sings about on “Work It Out” is more “all-encompassing,” he told Craig.
The positive reactions to the song, so far, have made Jonas feel “really good.”

“The power of music that we have, to be able to express what we’re going through and (the) healing process of that — being able to find relations with other people out there, it’s a good feeling,” he told Craig.
“It sounds like maybe the album was a bit cathartic for you,” Craig noted.

“Very much so,” Jonas replied. “I mean, look, I love therapy, but also for musicians it’s nice that we have that tool. That I can sit and journal ... sometimes putting pen to paper and paper to lyrics is relieving (and) rewarding.”
As for the album’s title, Jonas explained that it came to him very quickly and it perfectly captures how he’s feeling now.
“I kind of started with that. I said, ‘I want to make this body of work that is about where I’m at.’ Believer in love. Love is all around us. If you look for it, you’ll find it.”

title: Dolly Parton Says She's Read a Script for the '9 to 5' Remake. Will She Be In It?
summary: Dolly Parton talks about the "9 to 5" remake and if she would be involved in the movie.
story: Dolly Parton holds a special part in her heart for “9 to 5,” the 1980 comedy she co-starred with Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin.
The country music legend has been trying for years to come up with ideas for a sequel, but “it never happened” she told HuffPost in a new interview published May 21.

In 2024, it was reported that Jennifer Aniston would be producing  a remake with Diablo Cody writing the script. While the actor has yet to comment on the current status of the project, Parton said she's read a script.
“In Jennifer’s story, they wanted us to be involved in it somehow,” Parton said about her, Fonda and Tomlin. “But I love Jennifer. I think it’ll be a wonderful thing.”

“But we have no plans to be in that,” she added. “But I do wish her the best, because the script I read, I thought, was really good and a new and different take that really brings the office up to date the way that people live now.”
While Parton did not confirm or deny a possible cameo in the remake, she did share that she would still like to be a part of it somehow.

“I told her, I said, you’re more than welcome to use my song ‘9 to 5,’ and if you need some additional songs, or if you need the ‘9 to 5’ song rewritten or reworked, you know, to do that,” Parton said, adding that she would love to see how the film pans out and “love to be able to write some music, be involved in that way with it.”
“9 to 5” is about three very different working women who try to get revenge on their sexist boss. After abducting him, they create scenarios of how they would kill him.
A musical with music by Parton was created in 2008.
Last year, Tomlin also commented on the “9 to 5” remake, sharing how the original trio first tried to get a sequel up and running.

“We had one official crack at the script,” Tomlin told People in 2024. “The draft just didn’t work for us. We couldn’t really see the work world today (in the pages). People work from home. They take gig work. They don’t even know their boss. They’re at home!”
Tomlin said that when she heard the news about the remake she felt “rejected.”

“I felt sort of the same way I felt about the musical. You know, part of you feels rejected. You think that character’s yours always. And you could reembody it,” she told the magazine. “It’s going to be tough to make (the movie) happen. My sympathies are with Jennifer and her writer Diablo, who is a good writer.”

title: People Can’t Get Over the Way Tom Cruise Eats Popcorn: ‘His Best Stunt’
summary: Even after decades in the public eye, Tom Cruise still finds ways to surprise us. This time, it's the way he eats popcorn, and the internet can't get enough.
story: Even after decades in the public eye, Tom Cruise still finds ways to surprise us.

This May, the a-lister has been on a worldwide press tour for “Mission: Impossible — The Final Reckoning.” It’s the eighth and final movie in a franchise that has seen Cruise do his own stunts like hanging from the ceiling on a wire, scaling the Burj Khalifa in Dubai and riding a motorcycle straight off of a cliff into a gorge.

This latest film promises more wild stunts from the 62-year-old action star, including more hanging  — this time from a plane — but it’s a much less harrowing physical feat of his that’s garnering attention ahead of its release: the way he eats popcorn.

A short clip posted by X user @seifwtf shows Cruise in a movie theater in England, listening to a speaker announce he’s receiving a BFI Fellowship while enjoying a couple of handfuls of popcorn. He is eating it in a way that can only be described as “movie star who’s fully aware he is always being photographed.”

Cruise shakes handfuls of buttery popcorn like dice and tosses them into his mouth like a cartoon character or high-powered attorney might, spilling some kernels on the floor. It’s as entertaining as “Top Gun.”
And many folks on social media agree:

“He doesn’t even look like he’s eating it… (it) looks like he’s acting like he’s eating it.”“I’ve never seen another human being eat popcorn like Tom Cruise.”“When I forget how to eat in front of my crush.”“This is going to haunt me it’s so?? Menacing??? For no reason????”“He’s eating air.”“my dad eats his trail mix like this.”“Even the way he eats popcorn is intense.”“That popcorn technique is on par with the biplane sequence for his best stunt.”
“He doesn’t even look like he’s eating it… (it) looks like he’s acting like he’s eating it.”
“I’ve never seen another human being eat popcorn like Tom Cruise.”
“When I forget how to eat in front of my crush.”
“This is going to haunt me it’s so?? Menacing??? For no reason????”
“He’s eating air.”
“my dad eats his trail mix like this.”
“Even the way he eats popcorn is intense.”
“That popcorn technique is on par with the biplane sequence for his best stunt.”

Elsewhere on the tour, folks shared their popcorn-related Cruise stories. One X user shared a candid photo of Cruise speaking to movie theater staff in New York City while holding a big bucket of golden goodness.
“Tom Cruise has been talking to the employees at AMC Lincoln Square for 15 minutes now,” one X user posted on May 18, adding in a pair of follow-up posts that he was still going, minutes later.

“I’ll use this time to talk about the absolutely insane information Tom Cruise gave in his pre-screening speech,” replied another. “First, he asked us all not once but twice if we had popcorn (I showed him my bucket to confirm) and then he goes ‘I normally eat two big buckets myself during a movie.’”
On May 21, Cruise acknowledged the viral popcorn-eating moment during an interview on The Pat McAfee Show with Darius Butler, confirming he was not pretending to eat the popcorn.
“Man, I’m eating popcorn,” he said with a laugh. “They know when I’m going to these movies that I’m watching, I’m eating popcorn.”

This isn’t the only time Cruise went viral thanks to the cinematic snack: In 2023, during the last “Mission Impossible” press tour, Cruise posted himself saying six words that sum up the concession stand experience.
“I love my popcorn. Movies. Popcorn,” he said. So simple, and so true.

title: Former 'DWTS' Pro Lindsay Arnold On Why So Many Dancers On The Show Have Mormon Backgrounds
summary: Former "Dancing With The Stars" pro Lindsay Arnold gives her opinion as to why so many dancers on the show are or were Mormon.
story: Former "Dancing With the Stars" pro Lindsay Arnold is weighing in on why so many people from the Mormon community in Utah become professional ballroom dancers.

“I feel like in Utah, it’s very common, parents definitely want their kids to be doing an activity. That’s just kind of something that is, like, very prominent. Like, you put your kid in something and you really put them all in," Arnold, 31, said during a recent appearance on the “Hot Smart Rich” podcast.

The Provo, Utah native, whose younger sister, Rylee Arnold, later made her own debut as a “DWTS" pro in 2023, said the pair's parents "loved pushing" them in their dancing "passions" when they were kids because it kept them "out of trouble."
“If we weren’t at home for hours after school, just bored out of our minds looking for something to do, we weren’t getting in as much trouble," she explained.

“The Mormon culture," she continued, "is very much, like, we want our kids to be good kids and to not get into trouble and to not explore different things that could lead them in troubled areas,” she said.
“So I feel like a lot of parents put their kids in something and then push it hard," she added.
Lindsay Arnold began ballroom dancing as a child and competed on “So You Think You Can Dance” in 2012 before appearing as a pro dancer on “DWTS” from 2013 until 2022.
She described Utah’s dance culture as “very intense in the best way.”

"There’s been so many of us (from Utah) that have kind of paved the way that these dancers and parents see what’s possible," she said. "So they’re more willing to put (in) money, time. Because dance is a full-on investment.”

The Arnold sisters are just two of many "DWTS" dancers with connections to the Mormon community. The list also includes Witney Carson, Jenna Johnson, Ezra Sosa and siblings Julianna Hough and Derek Hough.

During an appearance on the “Lightweights” podcast in October 2024, "DWTS" pro Brandon Armstrong, who was raised Mormon in Napa, California, before relocating to Utah as a tween, shared why he thinks young people in Utah flock to ballroom dancing.
"There’s nothing else to do,” joked Armstrong. “What else do you do in Utah? Come on, our biggest cities, like Salt Lake, there ain’t nothing there.
He added, "You play sports, go to school, date super young — these guys get married when they’re 19, 20 years old — and then you dance.”

title: What Happens at the End of 'Sirens'? Star Julianne Moore Explains
summary: Julianne Moore unpacks the ending to Netflix's "Sirens" and why she thinks her character Michaela winds up in a "good place."
story: Warning: This post contains spoilers for "Sirens."
Is Michaela Kell's mysterious lifestyle really a cult? The question that loomed over the five episodes of Netflix's "Sirens" is finally answered in the finale, which premiered on May 22.
The resolution of an explosive weekend on a lavish New England island leaves no character unscathed, as the lives of the people in Michaela's orbit are completely upended.

Julianne Moore, who stars as Michaela in the series, tells TODAY.com the series started as a look at the Greek myth of sirens — winged creatures, half-birds and half-women, with songlike voices capable of luring sailors at sea to their demise.

“Why do we hear about the sirens from this perspective? We always hear about it from the sailors’ perspectives, not from the sirens’ perspective,” Moore says. “So it’s like, what are the sirens asking for? And in fact, why are they responsible and not the men?”
“The men are always saying, ‘These women lured me in. These women made me crash my ship. These women made me throw my life away.’ Suddenly, these men have no agency. They have no autonomy,” she adds.
Moore says it was the daughter of the series’ showrunner, Molly Smith Metzler, who asked her mom the questions about Greek sirens that led her to write the play the series is based on.
“I think Molly wanted to incorporate that idea into the show, this idea of, ‘What’s their story?’” Moore says.
What is 'Sirens' about?

The five-episode Netflix series also stars Meghann Fahy as Devon, who travels to the island after being unable to reach her sister Simone, played by Milly Alcock, who is employed as Michaela's assistant.

Devon's arrival on the island causes utter chaos in Michaela's perfectly precise and planned out life. The final episode starts at the end of the whirlwind weekend, as Michaela's annual gala is just beginning.

Michaela has been preparing for the event with beloved assistant Simone by her side for months, but the party gets upended when Michaela decides to fire her hours before it's set to begin. The socialite discovered that her husband, Peter Kell (Kevin Bacon), kissed Simone — and had photographic evidence to prove his infidelity.

While Simone insisted Peter came on to her and that she walked away after the kiss, the discovery came after Michaela found out Simone had been lying to her about her secret relationship with Peter's best friend Ethan (Glenn Howerton).

Simone and Ethan did go public with their relationship earlier in the season, leading him to propose to her, but Simone turned him down. After the rejection, Ethan began to spiral, and he fell off of a cliff while fighting with Simone.
How does 'Sirens' end?

The beginning of Episode 5 starts with Ethan recovering in the hospital, and when he sees Simone in the room, he starts screaming and telling her to get out. Kevin sticks up for Simone, telling Ethan he needs to respect her.
Moore says the series represents a push-and-pull of power dynamics between men and women. While it may look like Michaela is calling the shots, it’s really Peter who is pulling the strings all along.

“Peter Kell has all the power because he has all the money, and this is very much about social and economic hierarchy,” she says. “And when you really peel it back, you realize the person making the decisions, if you go all the way up, is that billionaire.”

After Peter asks Michaela why she fired Simone, he sees Simone running down to the beach. He follows her, and he tells her that the end of her employment was his fault and that he would fix it. She says she has to tell him something, but the scene cuts away.

The gala is in full swing back at the house as Devon confronts Michaela about the rumors she's a cult leader — and that she killed Peter's first wife — in front of all of the guests. Michaela shares that after Peter's divorce, his ex-wife had botched plastic surgery and became a recluse, shutting down all of the town gossip.

After the confrontation, Peter approaches Michaela and asks to talk to her in private. He then tells her he wants a divorce after he claims she kept him from his children from his previous marriage. He also reveals that he had found the photo of him and Simone — and destroyed it.
Moore says she thinks Devon's arrival on the island may have ignited the tension between Michaela and Peter, but adds their marriage was doomed no matter what.

"I think it was inevitable," Moore says. "I think these kind of situations, particularly in marriages, if that’s gonna happen, that’s gonna happen. So it’s not like Devon not coming would have changed anything. I think there would have been the same result."

After Michaela storms out of the room, Simone walks down a set of stairs wearing an evening gown. Peter extends his hand, and walks her out — signaling that what they talked about down at the beach was starting a real relationship.

As they walk into the gala, Simone sees Devon and fills her in that she's now with Peter, much to Devon's shock. Devon says she is going to go back to Buffalo to take care of their father, and the pair share a tearful goodbye when it's clear Simone is planning to stay on the island with Peter.
Simone gets up and gives a toast to the gala's attendees, standing in Michaela's usual place. Devon gets on a ferry back to the mainland.
On the ferry, she runs into Michaela and the pair have a heartfelt conversation about what's next for them.

"I think she’s ready to get on with her life," Moore says of her character. "In a sense, she’s kind of back to herself. She’s really back to someone who doesn’t know what her future is, but she has agency, and she’ll make decisions based on her own life and her own needs. So I actually think she’s in a good place."

The episode ends with a shot of Simone standing in front of Peter's home, looking out at what is now hers and thinking about all it took for her to get here — and what happened to the person who got in her way.

title: Willie Geist says he knew Ina Garten was a ‘good person’ because of this 1 sign
summary: Willie Geist shares more about his friendship with Ina Garten, including hanging out with her in Paris, and how he know she was a ‘good person.’
story: What makes a kind soul? Willie Geist seems to know the answer.
On May 19, he hosted his second-ever Sunday Sitdown Live with guest Ina Garten in front of a live studio audience at City Winery at Pier 57 in New York City.

At the event, the pair spoke on a range of topics, from what guests shouldn’t bring to a dinner party to what making pavlova with Taylor Swift was like, but it was backstage that Willie revealed more about his personal connection to Garten and a fateful lunch they shared together in Paris.

“We were there working for the Olympics last summer, and she sent me a text that said, ‘Let’s go have lunch,’” Willie tells TODAY.com, adding that Garten’s publicist and book editor Kate Tyler tagged along. “The three of us tucked into a little corner of a tiny little restaurant in Paris, and I felt like I was walking through a dream.”
Willie says watching Garten in her element “was a real highlight,” and he realized something about her at that table.

“We sat there for a long time and just talked about life, and she is a really curious person,” he says. “When you’re with her, it’s almost never about her. She’s just asking about you and wants to know about your family and your career, and she’s very curious. I think that’s always a sign of a good person.”

The pair of personalities, who enjoyed a kir royale and dessert platter onstage, have broken bread many times in the past. Garten has been a guest on Sunday TODAY in the past, where she spoke about her culinary journey and how she played a part in the Duchess of Sussex’s love story with Prince Harry.
Willie also appeared on Garten’s Food Network show “Be My Guest.” The prolific interviewer says he admires the way she handles herself with guests.
“She was incredibly prepared. She had reams of notes and questions,” he says, adding that he prides himself on being the first-ever guest on her show, which is now in its fifth season.

“Honest to God, I thought she was great,” Willie continues, adding that her chill vibe made it feel like they were just having lunch at her house. “It’s a good reminder of what it’s like to be on that side of it, about making our guests comfortable so that they open up more, reveal and feel like it’s a place where they can really share.”

title: See the top celebrity baby names of the decade
summary: Celebrity baby names run the gamut from traditional to original. Looking for inspiration? See 79 baby names celebrities choose in the 2020s.
story: Celebrities — they’re just like us. Except when it comes to choosing a baby name.

Sure, some celebs stick with traditional names — like Mindy Kaling’s baby Anne, and Bindi Irwin and Chandler Powell’s Grace — but many more of the celebrity babies born in the 2020s don’t have names high on the Social Security Administration’s list of most popular baby names.

From names found in nature — like Dove, Ocean and Daisy — to names inspired by jewels, like Goldie, Gemma and Sterling, the celebrity baby names of the 2020s so far run the gamut. One celebrity even named his son after “the greatest number of all time.”
More fun with baby names
Vintage baby names that are making a comebackBaby Naming 101: How to do itSee the most popular baby names in the U.S.
Vintage baby names that are making a comeback
Baby Naming 101: How to do it
See the most popular baby names in the U.S.
Celebrity babies of 2020
Aalam was born to Nicole Tuck and DJ Khaled on Jan. 19, 2020. Khaled said his son’s name means “world.”

Daisy Dove Bloom was born to Katy Perry and Orlando Bloom on Aug. 26, 2020. Perry said in an interview, “Daisy, to me, means pure, like purity. And Dove means peace, and Bloom kind of feels like it means joy, so, pure, peace and joy.”

Dove Mellencamp was born to Teddi Mellencamp and Edwin Arroyave Feb. 25, 2020. Mellencamp credits another reality star, Stassi Schroeder, for convincing Arroyave to use the name “Dove,” which is often associated with peace.
Eduardo Pau Lucas was welcomed by Hilaria and Alec Baldwin on Sept. 8, 2020. The couple’s fifth child’s name means “wealthy guardian of peace and light.”

Goldie Patricia born to Siri Pinter and Carson Daly March 26, 2020. The TODAY anchor explained “Goldie” is an Irish name and made him think of a “pot of gold.” Patricia is a nod to his mom who shares the same name.
Kaori Mai was born to Eniko and Kevin Hart Sept. 29, 2020. According to BabyNames.com, Kaori means “fragrant” while Mai stands for “dance.”
Khai Hadid was born to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik on Sept. 19, 2020. The name means “crowned” in Arabic, and was reportedly chosen for family reasons.
Lennon Love was born to Thomas Rhett and Lauren Akins Feb. 10, 2020. Rhett revealed the name Lennon was inspired by The Beatles’ John Lennon and Love was inspired by the Valentine’s Day holiday.
Pace was born to Jevon King and Diplo on March 19, 2020. While the DJ has never explained the origin of his son’s name, according to The Bump, it means “peace,” or “peaceful one.”
Phineas was born to Jessica Biel and Justin Timberlake on July 9, 2020. According to Ancestry.com, the name is associated with strength, courage and zeal.

Sovereign Bo was born to Jenn Goicoechea and Usher on Sept. 24, 2020. Usher said, “Sovereign, man, is such a beautiful word and name to me, you know, a supreme ruler is obviously the defined name ... She’s definitely ruling the household, but Sovereign Bo — Bo is at the end of it, so (she’s) my little ‘reign-bo.’ “

title: Alix Earle is joining 'Dancing with the Stars' Season 34
summary: Alix Earle shared she'll be joining Season 34 of "Dancing with the Stars" on her TikTok account.
story: Alix Earle is hitting the dance floor!
On May 22, the influencer posted about how she's joining the cast of Season 34 of "Dancing with the Stars" in a TikTok video of herself trying to do the whisk.
While strutting around a room in an all-white outfit, Earle turned toward the camera and shrugged before she started jumping up and down in glee.
Above the video, she wrote, "Me trying to do the whisk. It's okay... guess I'll learn this Season on DWTS."
In the comments, fans said they couldn't wait to see her on the dancing competition.
"I'm just getting up I can't BREATHE," one person wrote.
Another said, "This is gonna be epic" with the sparkles emoji.
A third added, "I CANT EFFIN WAITTTTT."
The official Instagram account of "Dancing with the Stars" also shared Earle's video on their Instagram story.
Earle, who boasts over 7 million followers on TikTok alone, isn't the only celebrity who revealed they'll be doing the show next season.
In April, "DWTS" announced that Robert Irwin, the son of the late Steve Irwin, will be on the program as well.

"11 year old me is beside himself right now 😂," Irwin shared on Instagram. "Bindi, thank you for inspiring me to take on this next adventure 🙌🏼☺️@dancingwiththestars, I’m so grateful for the life-changing experience ahead."
Robert Irwin will be following in the footsteps of his sister, Bindi Irwin. In 2015, she competed on the dance competition show with her partner, Derek Hough, and was crowned the winner of Season 21.
Bindi Irwin expressed in an Instagram post how happy she was that her brother is going to be on the show.

"Robert, you are going to absolutely shine in the ballroom," she wrote in the April 22 post. "I wish I could express the magnitude of how proud I am of you and everything you have achieved. Can’t wait to cheer you on each week as you inspire so many with your strength, kindness and determination."

"Here’s to an extraordinary journey ahead. Ps. Can’t believe it’s been 10 years since I won @dancingwiththestars with the most remarkable human being, @derekhough," she continued. "...So excited to be back in the ballroom celebrating my brother. 🎉."

title: Miley Cyrus reveals the vocal disorder for her 'super unique' voice — and why she won't fix it
summary: Miley Cyrus revealed the medical condition that's behind her unique voice, and why it impacts her ability to go on tour.
story: Miley Cyrus revealed the medical condition that's behind her unique voice, and why it impacts her ability to go on tour.
Cyrus shared more about her Reinke's edema diagnosis in an interview with Apple Music's Zane Lowe on May 21.

“I have the Reinke’s edema, which is something that is called, it’s abuse of the vocal cords,” Cyrus said. “And being 21 and staying up and drinking and smoking and partying after every show does not help. But also in my case, it does not cause it. So my voice always sounded like this — it's a part of my unique anatomy.”

Reinke's edema, also known as polypoid corditis or vocal cord edema, is a voice disorder caused by the swelling of the vocal chords, and occurs when fluid builds up in the outer layer of the vocal chords, according to Cleveland Clinic.
The disorder is most common in people with a long-term history of smoking, but people with chronic acid reflux, or a history of repetitive vocal trauma, like Cyrus, can also be affected.
The "Flowers" singer went on to add that she also has a large polyp on her vocal chord, which she says has given her "a lot of the tone and the texture" that has made her who she is as a performer.
"But it's extremely difficult to perform with, because it's like running a marathon with ankle weights on," she said.
Cyrus, 32, said that sometimes when she calls her mother, Tish Cyrus, at the end of the day, her mom tells her, "Oh, you sound like you're talking through a radio."
"And that's how you know I'm really tired, because it creates that ultimate vocal fry," Cyrus said. "And so I do have this blessing of a condition that I live with."
Cyrus said that even though she has both Reinke's edema and the large polyp on her vocal chord, she doesn't have plans to remove the polyp.
"I'm not willing to sever it, because the chance of waking up from a surgery and not sounding like myself is a probability," she said.
Cyrus told Lowe she plans a tour "like every other week," but that her health and other factors play into her actually going on the road to perform.

"I want to do it, but it would have to be in a way that is sustainable for me in all the ways that we talked about, and then also with what I got going on," she said. "Like, I don't lip sync. I sing live, and these songs are big."
She referred to two songs on her upcoming record, "Something Beautiful," which is set to drop on May 30.

"'End of the World' is a huge song, and 'More to Lose,' it's really strenuous, it's a big song. And so I don't write little songs," Cyrus said. "And even if you listen to the past albums, like 'Party in the U.S.A.,' maybe, if you're in the audience and you're singing along, it's one thing, but when you've got the mic and you're performing, it's totally different."
Cyrus also listed the logistics of traveling with a big crew, plus transporting the stage and lights, and needing to be able to play a certain amount of shows for it to "mathematically make sense."

"So really, the problem for me with touring, is not only me, because this is about connecting with people around the world and using my music as a tool to heal," she said. "I've always said, medicate a sick culture through these songs that I've created, or am creating. But the truth of it is is that touring, as much of it's an experience for the audience, it's a business for everybody else."

title: Who won ‘Survivor' 48? A recap of the finale
summary: Read a recap of the "Survivor 48" finale and find out who won the $1 million prize.
story: Warning: Major spoilers ahead for the finale of "Survivor" Season 48.
Who earned the title of “sole ‘Survivor’” at the end of Season 48 and walked away with the $1 million prize?
As the conclusion to “Survivor” 48 began on Wednesday, May 21, there were only five castaways remaining: Eva Erickson, Kyle Fraser, Mitch Guerra, Joe Hunter and Kamilla Karthigesu.
The three-hour finale included multiple surprising eliminations  before the winner was announced. So, as host Jeff Probst says every episode, “Let’s get it on!”
Who won 'Survivor' Season 48?
By the end of the three-hour Season 48 finale, just three castaways lasted to the Final Tribal Council: Kyle, Eva and Joe.
After the jury members' votes were cast, Probst continued the divisive recent tradition of announcing the winner then and there.
Kyle Fraser won "Survivor" 48, Probst revealed. Read on for how it all shook out.
What happened during the 'Survivor' 48 finale?

Following the blindside of Shauhin Davari in the penultimate episode, the final five returned to their Niu Nai camp to discuss Tribal Council. Eva and Joe thanked Kyle for tipping them off that Shauhin had turned on them, not realizing that Kyle and Kamilla concocted a plan to trick the duo into eliminating Shauhin.

Kyle pointed out in his confessional that he was in a good spot, with the option of either sticking beside his strongest ally, Kamilla, or going to the final three with Eva and Joe. But, he still had more obstacles to tackle, like winning the next immunity challenge. He also worried about how Eva planned to play her hidden immunity idol.
Meanwhile, Kamilla marveled at her lying abilities, adding that she planned to own all her deceptive game play if she made it to Final Tribal Council.
But first, the players had to unlock a puzzle that would give them an advantage in the next challenge. Eva secured the advantage by cracking the code.

At the next immunity challenge, which also included a pasta-filled reward, Probst welcomed the final five and explained that Eva's advantage allowed her to skip one of the ball toss sections. But despite the leg up, Kamilla pulled off the victory in a “massive comeback,” as the host said.

After Kamilla secured her spot in the final four, the other finalists had multiple conversations to decide who would join the jury as the next castaway voted out of “Survivor" 48. Although the obvious choice seemed to be to get rid of Joe, Kamilla and Kyle contemplated eliminating Mitch instead. They were convinced that Mitch could make a better pitch to the jury if he made it to the end of the game.

So when the second-to-last Tribal Council began, Mitch was a sitting duck. Kyle directly told Probst that Mitch's name was tossed around at camp. Mitch became emotional as he said it "sucked" knowing his game was over. But, he said he didn't have any regrets.
With Mitch getting his torch snuffed, the final four journeyed to the Niu Nai camp, again, and celebrated.

The next morning, the final four watched the sunrise together. In her confessional, Eva said she would take Joe to the end despite him being a strong competitor. Kamilla had a different plan for her other half in the game. She told Kyle she would select him to make fire against Joe. Kyle agreed with her thinking. As for Joe, he wanted to go to the end with Eva.

For the final immunity challenge, Probst said the final four would have to participate in a "Survivor" "classic." The ball challenge, called "Simmotion," which has appeared in multiple past seasons, required concentration and hand-eye coordination.

After a close battle with Joe, Kyle became the last “Survivor" 48 contestant to have the immunity necklace placed around his neck. He was also tasked with choosing which castaway would automatically join him in the finale, thus confirming the other two would have to participate in the fire-making challenge.

Kyle upheld a promise he made before the challenge and told Joe he was taking him to the final three, meaning Eva and Kamilla had to make fire. While prepping for the challenge, Eva became overwhelmed. Joe offered to take her spot, but she declined. So, he sat with her and shared some tips to improve her fire-making skills.

Before facing off, the jury looked stunned to learn that Kyle chose Joe. Each player then sat at their respective stations and began building their fires. Eva easily pulled off the victory, cementing her spot in the final three, as Kamilla struggled to get anything going.

On Day 26, the last day of the season, Kyle, Joe and Eva enjoyed their breakfast feast as viewers heard the jury — Cedrek McFadden, Chrissy Sarnowsky, David Kinne, Star Toomey, Mary Zheng, Shauhin, Mitch and Kamilla — share what they hoped to hear at Final Tribal Council.
As the sun set, Eva, Kyle and Joe made their way to Probst, ready to be grilled by the eliminated cast members.
Probst advised them, "Own your game and claim your victory," before the questions began.
Multiple secrets were spilled, including Kyle revealing his true occupation as a lawyer and his undercover partnership with Kamilla.

For their final pitches, Kyle said he was the most well-rounded player because he built strong relationships and played in the middle all season long. Joe spoke about being a 45-year-old firefighter and needing the money to take care of his family. Eva said  there has never been a player like her on the show and that she "embodied" the season by being "unprecedented."

After the votes were cast, Probst revealed that Kyle won, receiving five votes. Eva had two and Joe had one, marking a rare occasion in which all three finalists received votes at Final Tribal Council.
All the jury members congratulated Kyle, and he toasted his fellow "Survivor" cast members with champagne.

title: Kim Kardashian completes law program after 6 years
summary: After six years of study, Kim Kardashian has finished her law program and appears to be preparing for the bar exam.
story: The verdict is in: After six years of study, Kim Kardashian has finished her law program.

On May 21, Khloe Kardashian posted a series of Instagram stories of her sister's private graduation ceremony, which featured speeches about her years-long effort to be part of criminal justice reform.

In 2019, Kim Kardashian spoke about her passion for prison reform in an interview with Vogue, citing it as the driving force behind her decision to pursue a legal education. Despite having never obtained an undergraduate degree, the 44-year-old pursued a nontraditional legal education path known as “reading the law,” a program available in California and a number of other states. The approach allows individuals an opportunity to qualify for the bar exam under the mentorship of a licensed attorney.

Khloe Kardashian posted a video capturing her sister sitting on the side of a small stage as two of her mentors spoke about her achievements. Attorney Jessica Jackson, one of the mentors who sponsored Kim Kardashian during her studies, lauded her for putting in the work to achieve her goal while also working as a mother, businesswoman and public figure.

“It’s an absolute honor to stand here today, not just as mentors, but as witnesses to one of the most inspiring legal journeys we’ve ever seen,” Jackson said. “Six years ago, Kim Kardashian walked into this program with nothing but a fierce desire to fight for justice. No law school lectures, no ivory tower shortcuts, just determination and a mountain of case log books to read.”
Jackson underscored how Kim Kardashian allocated 18 hours a week, 48 weeks a year, for six straight years to study.
“That’s time she carved out while raising four children, running businesses, filming television shows and showing up in courtrooms to advocate for others,” Jackson noted.

In March 2025, E! News reported that Kardashian took the Multistate Professional Responsibility Exam (MPRE),  The National Conference of Bar Examiners notes that the MPRE is a requirement for bar admission in every U.S. jurisdiction (except Wisconsin and Puerto Rico).
Another one of Kim Kardashian's mentors commended her in the ceremony for focusing her efforts on marginalized groups.
Attorney and CNN political correspondent Van Jones was also in attendance and delivered a speech that captured the early skepticism surrounding Kim Kardashian’s legal ambitions and intentions.

“I’m trying not to get emotional,” he said before thanking Kim Kardashian for her efforts and praising her commitment to criminal justice advocacy. “Six years, seven years ago, when you were working on criminal justice, you were not embraced by anybody.”
Jones went on to recall how she chose to work with individuals he described as having been abandoned by society, and at times, their own families.
“The advocates are always last in line on the other, more popular causes," he explained. "It’s a lonely fight."
More photos capturing the event showed Kim Kardashian being celebrated by her sister Kourtney Kardashian Barker as well as a number of her children.

title: 5 foods you have to try at Epic Universe
summary: Here are five best savory and sweet food items to get across the five worlds at Universal Epic Universe from the PB&J Mac & Cheese Cone and DK Crush Float.
story: Sure, amusement parks are for the rides, but one could argue they’re really for the thematic food. And with Universal Epic Universe opening its portals on May 22, a lot of chatter is happening around new offerings that are as good as they look.

From viral sensations like the PB&J Mac & Cheese Cone and DK Crush Float, to the gruesome-looking but oh-so-satisfying Crimson Glazed Pork Belly, TODAY.com got to taste a plethora of options across Epic Universe, with one option for each of the five worlds.
Let’s dig in, shall we?
(Universal is owned by TODAY.com’s parent company, NBCUniversal.)
1. Crimson Glazed Pork
Location: Das Stakehaus, Dark Universe

If you’re looking for a meal that’s more filling (with some down time to digest in the aftermath), order the Crimson Glazed Pork Belly. The char siu-style pork belly comes with green onion mashed potatoes, roasted carrots, maitake mushrooms and acorn squash, with the finishing touch: bloody roast pork dipping sauce.
2. DK Crush Float

Location: The Bubbly Barrel, Super Nintendo WorldIt's easy to go bananas over this jumbo-sized treat with banana and pineapple soft serve in a waffle cone, topped with caramel popcorn and chocolate. You can get it in a regular plastic cup or upgrade to the souvenir Donkey Kong barrel mug.
3. Burning Cheddar Bites
Location: Burning Blade Tavern, Dark Universe

“Charred” on the outside, chewy on the inside. These round bites might look like they’d break your teeth (or at the very least, give you a strong burnt taste), but they are surprisingly soft and slightly crispy fried jalapeño pimento cheddar bites. An order comes with Sriracha ranch on the side.
4. Strawberry Yum Ice Cream
Location: Frosty Moon, Celestial Park

This ice cream flavor is true to its name. Strawberry ice cream is a classic treat in itself, but paired with strawberry cheesecake chunks and birthday sprinkles? A next-level sugar rush with an aesthetic to match.
5. PB&J (Pork, Bacon & Jam) Mac & Cheese Cone
Location: Hooligan’s Grog & Gruel, How to Train Your Dragon — Isle of Berk

Pulled pork and peanut bacon jam might not sound ideal to walk around with in the Florida heat, but the mild temperature of the meat and cheese paired with the garlic bread makes the PB&J a satisfying combo. Plus, the garlic bread cup makes a seemingly impractical snack an ideal grab-and-go meal.

title: Gillian Flynn reveals the alternate ending to ‘Gone Girl’ nobody else has read
summary: Gillian Flynn opens up about her imprint and writing process in a new interview.
story: When Gillian Flynn sits down to write a book, she never knows the ending.
Such was the case when the New York Times bestselling author wrote her thrilling novel-turned-film “Gone Girl,” she tells TODAY.com.

“I see it at the beginning. I always know my beginning scene,” Flynn says. "I pictured it with ‘Gone Girl — a man coming home to a house and the door is wide open, and that moment of feeling like, ‘Why is the door wide open?’”

As a self-proclaimed true crime fanatic, Flynn says her initial scenario invoked fear around, “What would it be like to have your spouse mysteriously disappear? And everyone says, ‘It’s always the husband.’”

“And you cannot not look guilty. Because if you’re crying, people say, ‘Oh, he’s putting on a show.’ And if you’re not crying, people say, ‘Oh, he doesn’t care. He’s a freak.’” she adds. “So, you know, I started playing with that from there.”
For any book Flynn writes, be it her 2006 debut "Sharp Objects" or 2012's “Gone Girl,” the plot unfolds as she gets inside her characters' heads.
This means Flynn reaches the story's end nearly at the same point the reader does — but she gets to choose how the characters are remembered in their final moments on the page.
For “Gone Girl,” Flynn says the twisted ending readers now know didn’t always exist. Instead, she tells TODAY.com how the book originally painted characters Amy and Nick.

“There was the one (ending) I was originally going to go with — that you didn’t know that Amy had framed Nick until the very end, so you didn’t meet Amy at all,” Flynn says, explaining that the draft's entire story was “all Nick’s point of view as he’s bouncing around, looking more and more guilty.”

In this end of the story, which “no one read” aside from Flynn, the reader would have discovered Amy framed the man they’d been following for the entire novel, naturally prompting more sympathy for Nick.

“And then I started thinking, ‘Who is this woman who did all this stuff?’ I kept getting obsessed with, ‘Who would do this?’ And so then I was like, ‘I need Amy in this story. I can’t hide her until then. That’s no fun,’” Flynn says.
As readers know, Amy became the focal point of the page-turner. But Flynn wrote other endings, too.

“I had the Ozark grifters come back into (Amy’s) life at the end and frame her,” Flynn says. “I did have one ending where she was going to go to jail and that lasted for a day, literally. I was like, ‘She would never go to jail. Amy would never go to jail.’”
Though Flynn is known for her twists, she says she's more interesting in making points about the human psyche and larger-scale world issues.
“I always say, I write character studies and themes, and I hide it all inside the chocolate of a juicy mystery, so that I can get people to read it,” she says.
Now, Flynn is working on screenwriting and also became a publisher herself, starting her own imprint, Gillian Flynn Books, with upcoming titles like Danie Shokoohi's "Glass Girls."
Flynn chatted with TODAY.com about her books, her new imprint and the advice she'd give aspiring authors.
This interview has been edited.
How did you decide to make the move into publishing with Gillian Flynn Books?
It started with Molly Stern, who was my publisher during “Gone Girl,” asking me if I'd be interested in an imprint.

I wasn't looking to have an imprint. But I realized I could create my own mission statement and could make sure there were voices getting out there who weren't just copying whatever previous popular book was, falling into a pre-arranged shape or done only by people who already have platform.
I find a really dangerous trend, that this current market is really squashing out the kind of voices that I love, which are the quirky, weird, off kilter, not easy to put inside a box.

The current series that I’m publishing, Margot Douaihy’s series, is about a punk rock former addict nun who is totally tattooed and solves mysteries in New Orleans. Or Stacy Horn’s nonfiction book, “The Killing Fields of East New York,” is all about white collar crime and how it decimated a community. These are things that aren’t necessarily going to get snapped up immediately. And I wanted to give that voice.
Was it intentional that all the authors you've published so far have been female?
It is not. It has just happened to be the ones that have come to me that I really, really love. It has not been an intentional thing, but it has been the ones so far that have really drawn me.
Would you agree the audience predominantly consuming crime and thriller storylines are women? Why do you think that is?

I think women are more acquainted with fear than men are. We live with it as part of our everyday. Hopefully it doesn’t obsess you or control you too much, but I don’t know any woman who doesn’t, in the very back of her mind go, ‘" could walk out the door and if I walk down the wrong corner, if I stay out too late, if I get in the wrong place, something really, really bad could happen to me." I don’t know very many women who haven’t had some sort of close up moment that made them a little frightened. I mean, we all carry that with us.

I think the crime genre, when it’s done right, really can touch on that issue and give us a vocabulary and a means to talk about it, and give us almost a way to purge that fear a little bit — understanding that it’s out there and that I’m not crazy. Sometimes you have that moment of, like, ‘"m I crazy to be nervous in this situation? Is it me?" And the answer is f------ better safe than sorry.
Writing wise, what are you working on right now?

I’m working on a lot, writing wise. Most of it is screenplay stuff. Ever since I did adapted “Gone Girl” for the screen, I’ve been really attracted to screenwriting and creating film and TV. And that’s largely because I grew up in a household where my mom taught reading and my dad taught film. And so, to me, they’re both equally viable ways of telling a story.
The one I’m most excited about is adapting “Dark Places," my second book, for HBO. It's not official yet, but fingers crossed.

I’ve told myself that after I get these couple projects done, that I’m going to shut down that part for a little bit and just finish this book I’m writing. It’s daunting writing a book after “Gone Girl.” You have the demons on your shoulder going, “Is this too much like ‘Gone Girl’? Is it not enough like ‘Gone Girl’?”
What is your initial writing process like?

I write in my head all the time. I can’t turn it off. I was writing something in my head on the way to work today, on the way to the office, that is not going to go anywhere. It was just something I was thinking about, like, “Oh, it’s a great line. What is that? Where’s that line go?” It’s describing a character or describing a moment or scenery.

One of the walls in my office is a whiteboard. It's got whiteboard wallpaper just entirely on it, which is fantastic for a writer. But it looks like the scribblings of a mad woman because I just write different ideas for different projects. People will look at it and it really does look like a crazy person because it's all over.
Do you still write down those random ideas?

Yeah. I’ll probably never remember where it’s at or to look at it. But every once in a while I do go like, “Ah, I wrote that down somewhere.” But I’m like, “Did I write in my email? Did I write on my wall. Is it in a notebook?”
What does the rewriting process look like for you?

I loop around and rewrite a little bit as I go. But my aim is generally to get a crappy first draft.
